column13: Solution Description

The Lynas Malaysia plant primarily uses natural gas and electricity, with some diesel consumed in machines and processes. During the year, Lynas Malaysia signed a 1MW onsite solar installation contract. Implementing onsite solar installations at Lynas Rare Earth's facilities is a commendable step towards Sustainability and reducing the environmental footprint of its operations.

column6: Reductions in energy requirements of products and services
Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: Mt Weld uses groundwater and recycled water; The Kalgoorlie Rare Earths Processing Facility uses treated grey water supplied by the City of Kalgoorlie-Boulder; in Lynas, Malaysia, it uses scheme water (city water) provided by the local water utility provider.
The total water withdrawn is 5,895,628 per m3.
The total water being discharged is 48.7%.
The total water consumption is 6,452,685 per m3.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
column7: The Mt Weld mine site is on approximately 2500 hectares of mining leases.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: At Mt Weld, Lynas implements an Environmental Management Plan approved by the EPA. Our Environmental Management Plan includes a mitigation hierarchy that sets objectives and targets for flora, fauna, surface water, and groundwater.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Monitoring groundwater seepage is crucial for ensuring environmental integrity and safety of mining and processing operations, especially in the Lynas Rare Earth. Lynas Rare Earth We perform quarterly groundwater seepage monitoring surrounding our Mt Weld tailings storage facilities with water analysis performed by an independent third party. Since commencing Mt Weld operations, no groundwater quality impact has been recorded.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Vegetation health monitoring is integral to Lynas Rare Earth's commitment to environmental stewardship and Sustainability. In addition, 15 years of vegetation health monitoring has shown no significant impacts on flora surrounding the Mt Weld site.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Annual Rehabilitation Monitoring, including vegetation trials, is undertaken, and 5 years of monitoring data has been obtained. The mountainous vegetation surrounding the Mt Weld site was surveyed by biodiversity experts in September 2020 and assessed as "excellent condition", the second highest rating available.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Mt Weld also has an approved Radiation Management Plan (RMP) as prescribed by the Mines Safety and Inspection Act, 1994, with a tenth iteration approved by the Department of Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety in March 2022. Ongoing monitoring has shown there is no increase in background radiation.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column8: Social and Cultural Heritage Management Plan
column13: Lynas signed a Social and Cultural Heritage Management Plan (SCHMP) in consultation with the Nyalpa Pirniku group in FY23. The SCHMP will ensure future best-practice management of cultural heritage sites across the expansion area and minimize risks to heritage sites.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Reconciliation endorsed Lynas' first Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP) Australia in April 2023. The Reconciliation Action Plan (RAP) is the first stage of Lynas's reconciliation journey in Australia.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: During the year, the Kalgoorlie Rare Earths Processing Facility's first Compliance Assessment Report (CAR) was submitted from February 2022 to January 2023 to the Department of Water and Environment Regulation (DWER). The CAR provides an update on activities taken during the reporting period, including environmental monitoring and rehabilitation activities to minimize impacts on visual amenities.\t

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: During the year, several seeding trials were completed on our Kalgoorlie site and old tracks were rehabilitated within the buffer area. We plan two irrigation areas to plant our first seedlings growing at the Kalgoorlie-Boulder Urban Landcare Group (KBULG) nursery.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: The Environmental Radiological Monitoring Program is crucial to ensure compliance with regulations, protect the environment, and address concerns related to radiological safety. The Environmental Radiological Monitoring Program covers 1 km, 5 km, 10 km and 20 km from the Lynas Malaysia plant.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: Lynas Rare Earth intends to manage and mitigate its environmental impact. The plan typically includes strategies, measures, and procedures to ensure compliance with environmental regulations, promote Sustainability, and minimize adverse environmental effects.

Lynas anticipates that most of the Project's post-mining land use will be 'Pastoral Land'. Lynas committed to rehabilitating all disturbed areas to the agreed final land use(s). The proposed post-mining land use has been discussed with key stakeholders throughout the life of the Project.

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column13: A vegetation assessment for Lynas Rare Earth should involve the evaluation of plant species, biodiversity, and the overall health of vegetation in and around its facilities. This assessment is essential for understanding the environmental impact of operations and implementing effective conservation measures.

column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations
column13: Conducting a groundwater analysis is crucial for assessing the quality and potential impacts of Lynas Rare Earth's operations on local groundwater resources. Lynas Rare Earth can establish regulatory requirements, protect groundwater resources, and contribute to responsible and sustainable mining practices.

column7: In FY23, the total direct GHG emissions were 84,238 tonnes of CO2-e.
In FY23, The total indirect GHG emissions is 45,580 tonnes of CO2-e.
Lynas conducts Life Cycle Assessments for our products, and we have calculated an emission average of 30kg CO2-eq per kg of REO from our internal LCA on a 2019 basis.

column13: In FY23, scenario analysis was undertaken to identify and assess exposure to climate-related physical risks and opportunities to increase resilience. The analysis was conducted by F.M. Global and included engineering data from site visits and climate change insights and data.

In the ESG Report, Lynas released the results of the Life Cycle Assessment for permanent magnet motors used in water pumps, conducted in conjunction with value chain partners. It assessed the manufacturing data from two electric motor pumps: an induction motor using a copper coil for an electromagnet and a permanent magnet motor using neodymium-iron-boron magnets.

The pump manufacturing from rare earth permanent magnets was shown to have 50% lower carbon dioxide equivalent emissions over 10 years, producing 75% lower carbon dioxide equivalent emissions. In addition, the permanent magnet motor pump was 50% lighter than the induction motor pump.\t

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts

column13: In line with the circular economy, Lynas' approach to our industrial by-products prioritizes initiatives to reduce, reuse, and recycle and only implement safe long-term storage/disposal. The prioritization of industrial by-products can vary depending on various factors, including environmental impact, economic value, and regulatory considerations.

Waste management involves numerous systems to control waste management processes and identify the most appropriate disposal methods as a last resort. All waste materials are stored and disposed of safely and environmentally responsible.

At Mt Weld and Kalgoorlie, all Controlled Waste is traceable via the Department of Water and Environment Regulation (DWER) waste tracking network. A waste tracking network is a system or infrastructure that monitors, records and manages waste materials throughout their lifecycle.
